welcome to the VMware on AWS update show

for this month we have updates covering
a number of different services and as
lever let's start with VMware Cloud on
AWS as mentioned in last month's show
with the latest VMware Cloud on AWS
release version 1.22 there were some
enhancers made to elastic DRS this month
we've made those enhancements now
available to all VMware Cloud on AWS
customers via the new elasticity tab
we've had some compliance news in the
last month with VMware Cloud on AWS
achieving PCI compliance in the
remaining regions which means all VMware
Cloud on AWS regions except for govcloud
are now PCI Compliant and we've also
achieved Germany C5 certification
the rollout of our latest instance type
i4i continues with availability now in
Bahrain Cape Town Milan Mumbai Osaka and
Stockholm and we see a further update to
the vmc Sizer version 5.3.1 which has
added a new host based Sizer capability
this allows for reverse sizing where you
can see what available capacity there is
depending on how many hosts you have in
a cluster
for VMware Services VMware site recovery
has had some exciting updates which
we'll dive into later in the show in
summary the limit for replication also
known as recovery Point objective or RPO
has been reduced down to one minute from
five minutes and we've seen Bahrain
added as a new region for VMware site
recovery which brings the Region's
VMware site recovery is available in to
23. plus support has been added for new
replication topologies that use VMware
Cloud on AWS Outpost
via my cloud director service has seen
some minor Updates this month with
improvements to the SDC Association
workflow additional security
capabilities to allow IP restrictions to
CDs instances enhancements to email
notifications and proxy enhancements for
networks that don't permit outbound
connections lastly for service updates
we've seen a new release for VMware
converter version 6.4 VMware converter
is a great tool if you have physical
servers you wish to migrate to VMware
cloud and AWS or if you have servers
that you're migrating from environments
where you can't install common migration
tools such as HDX version 6.4 adds lots
of new support for Hardware devices such
as nvme disk controllers and power
virtual Skizzy disk controllers it adds
support for vcenter and esxi version 8
and adds conversion support for Amazon
ec2 instances that means that with
VMware converter you can now migrate
Amazon ec2 instances into VMI Cloud on
AWS
finally to wrap up the updates this
month we have a new blog article
covering simplifying operations for

VMware Cloud on AWS

this month we've seen enhancements to
VMware site recovery and to take us
through those updates we're joined by
Greg Vinton welcome to the show Greg
hey Chris uh hey Natasha excited to be
on the show for the first time and uh
excited to share some updates for VMware
site recovery
excellent so to get us started can you
give us an overview of VMware site
recovery
yeah sure so uh VM site recovery uh
first of all is a cloud-based Disaster
Recovery Service so what that means for
customers is it gives them a really
simple way to provide Dr capabilities
for workloads that they're running both
on premise and also in VMware cloud and
AWS because it also uses VMware cloud
and AWS as the disaster recovery site
this has a bunch of benefits for
customers as well the real key benefit
though for a customer is that they don't
have to have an on-premise data center
up and running all the time that they
have to manage and have investments into
for a disaster recovery site they can
leverage VMware Cloud on AWS for the
recovery site and scale this up and down
based on their requirements it's very
easy to build out your recovery plans
based on your recovery Point objectives
or rpos and also build plans out on your
recovery time objectives or rtos the
main part for customers that really
resonates with them though is the
ability to easily test their Disaster
Recovery plans we find with customers a
lot of the time that they have a
disaster recovery plan in place but it's
so hard to test that they negate testing
it so with the Insight VMware site
recovery it's very easy to test these
plans and then when you have a Dr event
very easy to enable them as well so
these are probably the key benefits that
resonate with a lot of our customers
thanks that Greg can you give us an
example of how our customers have been
using
using they're key the key use case that
we see most of the time is that Disaster
Recovery use case but there's a number
of different architectures that we see
customers use VMware site recovery with
their production sites the first one is
I guess a simple design they have a
primary data center that's running
either on premise or in VMware cloud and
AWS and they're protecting that with
VMware site recovery the second one that
we see is what we call a fan in topology
and so they'll have multiple sites
whether that's multiple on-premise data
centers or multiple VMware Cloud on AWS
production sites or a combination of
both protecting those into different AWS
regions using VMware site recovery we
also actually see customers use VMware
site recovery to migrate their workloads
from on-premise into VMware Cloud on AWS
so there's a number of use cases around
that as well
excellent and in the last month we've
seen some exciting enhancements to
VMware site recovery uh can you tell us
a little more about those changes yes
sure so uh there's always uh exciting
news when it comes to VMware cloud and
AWS but there has been some really good
updates in the last month for VMware
site recovery specifically uh the first
one is the lowering of the recovery
Point objective
um so this used to sit at a minimum of
five minutes RPO that's now down to one
minute so for customers that are really
trying to get almost to what we call
synchronous replication or very low RPO
this is a great offering for customers
that are looking at a synchronous or
lower than one minute RPO will typically
look at something like a VMware stretch
cluster for them as well there's been
some other enhancements through Auto
scaling and load balancing so when we're
protecting workloads into the recovery
site they actually get load balanced
across the different hosts in VMware
Cloud on AWS so when you do have a
recovery or you're testing your plans
those workloads are already balanced
across the disaster recovery site the
next one is the ability to Auto scale
out that recovery site based on the
required resources so when you're
protecting your production sites or your
protected sites into your recovery site
using the VMware site recovery the
recovery site can automatically scale up
to handle those protected workloads as
they scale as well and we've had some
recent expansions to different AWS
regions that are supported with VMware
site recovery the latest one is the
Bahrain region and that now takes us up
to 23 regions globally that are
supported for VMware site recovery which
is which is super exciting the final one
is just around this new supported
topologies so for customers that have a
VMware Cloud on AWS outposts deployment
in in their on-premise data centers they
can now protect workloads between
outposts environment using VMware site
recovery and the final one is the
topology around protecting VMware Cloud
on AWS workloads using VMware site
recovery to a VMware Cloud on AWS
Outpost environment so they're the main
updates for for this month that I'm sure
there's going to be more in in the next
month as well Greg how do customers get
started with VMware site recovery
uh for customers that are leveraging
VMware cloud and AWS today it's very
easy because it's a cloud service you
can go and activate VMware site recovery
in your environment today and you're up
and running very quickly it will also
provide you with the template to deploy
the on-premise appliance once you've
done that you can start creating your
what we call Protection groups and
Recovery plans to start protecting your
workloads so very very easy to get up
and running great thanks for your time
Greg and thanks for diving deep on those
those updates and uh that about wraps up
our update around VMware site recovery
thank you for your time Greg
thanks team appreciate it I'll see you
soon
